modules.title: Descriptive Statistics
modules.description: Measures of central tendency and variability

modules.title: Sampling & Distributions
modules.description: Sampling methods and the central limit theorem

items.prompt: A dataset has the following values: 5, 8, 12, 15, 20. What is the mean?
For the dataset: 3, 7, 7, 9, 12, what is the median?
items.explanation: The median is the middle value when data is ordered. With 5 values, the median is the 3rd value: 7

items.prompt: Which measure of central tendency is most affected by outliers?
items.explanation: The mean includes every value in its calculation, so extreme values (outliers) pull it toward them. The median only depends on the middle position.

items.prompt: A sample has variance of 16. What is the standard deviation?
items.explanation: Standard deviation is the square root of variance. √16 = 4

items.prompt: When should you use the median instead of the mean?
options: When data has outliers or is skewed
items.answer_key: When data has outliers or is skewed
items.explanation: The median is resistant to outliers and is the better measure of center for skewed distributions.

items.prompt: A score of 85 comes from a distribution with M = 100 and SD = 15. What is the z-score?
A z-score of +2.0 means the score is:
items.explanation: A z-score indicates how many standard deviations a score is from the mean. z = +2 means 2 SDs above.

items.prompt: What percentage of scores fall below a z-score of 0?
items.explanation: A z-score of 0 is exactly at the mean, and 50% of scores fall below the mean in a normal distribution.

items.prompt: In a normal distribution, approximately what percentage of scores fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean?
items.explanation: The empirical rule states that 68% of data falls within ±1 SD of the mean.

items.prompt: In a normal distribution, the mean equals the median.
items.explanation: The normal distribution is symmetric, so the mean and median are equal and located at the center.

items.prompt: A distribution has positive skew. Which statement is true?
items.explanation: In a positively skewed distribution, the tail extends to the right, pulling the mean higher than the median.

items.prompt: The null hypothesis typically states that:
items.explanation: The null hypothesis (H₀) represents the default position that there is no effect, no difference, or no relationship.

items.prompt: If p = .03 and α = .05, you should:
options: Fail to reject the null hypothesis
items.explanation: Since p (.03) is less than α (.05), the result is statistically significant and we reject H₀.

items.prompt: A Type I error occurs when you:
options: Fail to reject a false null hypothesis
items.explanation: Type I error (false positive) means concluding there is an effect when there actually is not.

items.prompt: Which t-test should you use to compare scores before and after an intervention in the same participants?
items.explanation: The paired (dependent) samples t-test is used when comparing two measurements from the same participants.

items.prompt: The degrees of freedom for an independent samples t-test with n₁=15 and n₂=20 is:
A correlation of r = -0.85 indicates:
items.explanation: The absolute value |r| = 0.85 is strong (> 0.5), and the negative sign indicates an inverse relationship.

items.prompt: If r = 0.60, what is r² (coefficient of determination)?
items.explanation: r² = 0.60² = 0.36, meaning 36% of the variance in one variable is explained by the other.

items.prompt: A significant correlation proves causation.
items.explanation: Correlation does not imply causation. A relationship between variables does not mean one causes the other.

items.prompt: If you flip a fair coin twice, what is the probability of getting two heads?
items.explanation: P(H on first) × P(H on second) = 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25

items.prompt: The standard error of the mean decreases as:
items.explanation: SE = s / √n. As n increases, the denominator gets larger, making SE smaller.

items.prompt: In the regression equation Ŷ = 10 + 3X, what does the 3 represent?
items.explanation: The slope (b) indicates how much Y changes for each 1-unit increase in X. Here, Y increases by 3 for each 1-unit increase in X.
